results.title: Comics That Read Top to Bottom Are Bringing in New Readers

results.title: The Jewish Deli: An American Tale Told in Pickles and Pastrami
results.abstract: “I’ll Have What She’s Having,” a traveling exhibit on the Jewish delicatessen, looks back at a vibrant institution fueled by immigration and irresistible food.

media.caption: The challenge of a museum exhibition on cuisine: conveying taste and smell in a gallery where food is not allowed. This attempt to fabricate a corned beef sandwich created a bit of a crisis for curators.
media.copyright: Joel Barhamand for The New York Times

results.title: Mississippi Fires Lawyer Trying to Recoup Misused Welfare Funds

results.title: Jail Officer Charged in Killing Claims Gel Pellets Felt Like Glass Shards

results.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
results.title: In Japan, Abe Suspect’s Grudge Against Unification Church Is a Familiar One
results.abstract: The man accused of killing Shinzo Abe said his mother’s huge donations to the church bankrupted his family. Many others in Japan have similar stories.

media.caption: Tomihiro Tanaka, president of the Japanese branch of the Unification Church, during a moment of silence for former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at a Tokyo news conference last week.

results.adx_keywords: Renting and Leasing (Real Estate);Real Estate and Housing (Residential);United States Economy;Interest Rates
results.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Ben Casselman
results.title: We Need to Keep Building Houses, Even if No One Wants to Buy
results.abstract: Right now, builders have too many homes and not enough people to sell them to. In the long term, the United States has the opposite problem: Not enough houses for all the people who want them.

media.caption: “We’re going to look project by project and say which ones are we are going to go ahead on and which we are going to take a pause on,” said Randal Lewis of the Lewis Group of Companies, which is doing work in Chino, Calif.
media.copyright: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

results.title: In 5 National Parks, Hidden Gems and Roads Less Traveled
results.abstract: As park visitation rises, serenity in nature can be elusive. But even the most popular U.S. national parks have overlooked treasures and entrances that aren’t clogged with traffic.

results.adx_keywords: Pregnancy and Childbirth;Teenage Pregnancy;Fistulas;Abortion;Teenagers and Adolescence;Children and Childhood
results.title: What Pregnancy and Childbirth Do to the Bodies of Young Girls
results.abstract: An Ohio 10-year-old’s recent abortion has generated fierce debate. Doctors in countries where pregnancy is common in adolescents say the toll of childbirth on young bodies is brutal.

media.caption: An X-ray of a healthy 10-year-old girl. Doctors who work in countries with underage pregnancies say a critical health issue is that the pelvis of a child is too small to allow passage of even a small fetus.
media.copyright: Department of Radiology, U.C. San Diego Health

results.adx_keywords: Art;Nineteen Hundred Sixties;Museums;Civil Rights Movement (1954-68);Warhol, Andy;Celant, Germano;Chryssa (1933-2013);Di Suvero, Mark;Johns, Jasper;Rauschenberg, Robert;Schneemann, Carolee;Jewish Museum (Manhattan, NY);Manhattan (NYC)
results.title: When ‘New Art’ Made New York the Culture Capital
results.abstract: Artists in the early 1960s drew from a heady mix: Mad magazine and Marilyn; the civil rights movement and the death of a president; queer bodies and “Pieta.” It’s all at the Jewish Museum.

media.caption: “New York 1962-1964,” opening Friday at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan, from left: Roy Lichtenstein’s “Thinking of Him,” 1963; Marjorie Strider’s “Girl with Radish,” 1963; Rosalyn Drexler’s “Self-Portrait,” 1964.
media.copyright: Rosalyn Drexler/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York; Lila Barth for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Jews and Judaism;Arabs;Music;Poetry and Poets;Art;Folk Music;Israel
results.title: Below an Israeli City, a Musical Harmony Belies the Tensions Above Ground
results.abstract: In an underground reservoir built 1,233 years ago in a city that saw sectarian riots last year, visitors hear a beguiling musical composition that combines Arab love songs with Hebrew poetry.

media.caption: Visitors at the Pool of the Arches, a subterranean reservoir beneath Ramla, a city in Israel with a mixed population of Arabs and Jews.
media.copyright: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Bicycles and Bicycling;Content Type: Service;Electric and Hybrid Vehicles;Cycling, Mountain Bike;Exercise;Roads and Traffic;Cycling, Road
results.title: The Reluctant Rider’s Guide to Biking
results.abstract: The cycling world can be intimidating, even for those who grew up in it. But that’s no reason to let your pandemic wheels gather dust.

media.caption: Long gone are the days when you could put an extra-terrestrial in the basket of your bicycle and evade government scientists. But many people still find biking deeply satisfying.
media.copyright: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
